newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish treasury to borrow less by Nov - minister.
newsitem.headline: Turkish treasury to borrow less by Nov - minister.

text.p: Turkey's treasury will borrow less by the end of October due to its reduced cash need, state minister Ufuk Soylemez said.

"From now on, the treasury will not be in a strong need to borrow in domestic markets. However, it might open small scale borrowing auctions if needed," Soylemez, responsible for the treasury and privatisation, told Reuters.
The treasury sold an unexpectedly high 198.1 trillion lira of two-year inflation-indexed bonds on Tuesday to meet Wednesday's bond redemption of 288.2 trillion lira.
The risk premium rose to 32 percent in the acution, up two points from the previous auction on May 13 when it sold only 55.27 trillion lira of similar bonds.
Soylemez blamed market fears of possible early elections for the rise in risk premiums.
Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's coalition government unveiled its plan on Sunday to call for snap elections. No specific date for the elections has been set.
"Macro-economic balances are under our control. No one can distort the present stability even in an election atmosphere," Soylemez said.
He said one billion marks, to be raised through a five-year Eurobond issue, would help the central bank to keep its reserves stable in coming months.
The issue, led by lead managers Commerzbank and Westdeutsche Landesbank, was set on Tuesday.
